events.description: Black screen with white text listing interview segments for "Zooey Deschanel - 'Bridget'" from "Trolls," including timestamps and topics.
Woman in navy top speaks expressively, gesturing with hands near chest and outward, seated before vibrant animated forest backdrop.
Woman looks upward, mouth open mid-sentence, hands resting, beginning to speak with slight head tilt.
Woman continues speaking, eyes slightly off-camera, one hand moving toward chest, beginning to gesture.
Woman speaks with raised hands, palms up, then toward chest, eyes wide, emphasizing her words with animated gestures.

segments.text: The movie's about sort of a long-standing, um,
There's a conflict between two different species, the trolls and the bergens.
And the bergens are bigger and they like to eat trolls.
And, um, they've kind of been abusing these trolls for years.
And finally the trolls escape.
And the trolls, um, live peacefully for a long time and then the bergens rediscover them.
They, one of them gets captured and the other friends go to get the captured one.
Um, and, um, my character is kind of a, um, servant, Bergen.
And, um, she ends up helping the trolls, um, survive.
Bridget's a really sweet, um, kind of guileless character.
She, um, works for the, uh, the main chef to the king and the, the main chef is very, um, mean and cruel and kind of, um,
You know, uh, kicks Bridget around, really.
Bosses her around and is kind of a little bit abusive toward her.
And Bridget has a big crush on the king.
Um, she's in love with him.
And that's her kind of main motivation.
She has this kind of like spark of
Love and happiness inside her that none of the other Bergens have.
But she's a little kind of um, you know, uh, scullery maid.
Bridget helps the trolls, um, basically there's that kind of an agreement.
Poppy, who's the main, one of the main trolls, um, offers to help Bridget win the king over by, you know, dressing her up and making her into this more sophisticated
Lady named Lady Glitter Sparkles.
Um, and um, it's kind of like a little Cinderella-esque micro story within the broader story.

Bridget and King Gristle meet officially when she's dressed up as Lady Glitter Sparkles and she, you know, he believes that she's the sophisticated lady and he falls in love with her and they go on a, um, roller skating date and, um, eat pizza and connect on a lot of things.
But then she has to leave right away because, you know, she's pretending to be somebody that she's not.
I just thought about like what her voice would sound like cause it wasn't, sometimes you do a, you know, an animated thing and you kind of sound like yourself.
Well, this was very different and I, I don't really sound like myself.
So we, we really played a lot, um, in the room and I, you know, I just thought a lot about it, but beforehand, but, um, but it, we experimented a lot with where

Bridget, like, how Bridget's voice sounds and, and then how Lady Glitter Sparkle's voice sounds, like how it changes when she's trying to appear more sophisticated, um, and how much of a change, um, that was and we kind of went kind of far and then dialed it back and then found a really good, um, you know, happy medium.
Mike and Walt are so amazing, such great directors.

It was great to work with them because they really, even though I wasn't getting to work with the other actors, um, when I was recording my voice parts, they're the types of directors that can kind of create the world for you without, you know, me having to have the other actors there, you know, um, and they'd kind of switch off, you know, reading the parts and

Um, they are just, they really allowed me to also explore the character and really find the character's voice because some people might just say, you know, just do your own voice or, you know, or they really let me play with it.
So, um, I'm so grateful to them.
Music makes everyone happy, I think.
Most people happy.
And I think that's part of the, you know, the trolls, like, key to their happiness.
And, um, I think kind of when the Bergens start joining in on that, that's when they're finding their own happiness.
It was so great working with Justin.
He was such a, like, supportive producer and, um,

Had, you know, he also is a great actor, so he was really able to, like, have a perfect mix of being able to, like, guide, you know, the vocal performance from both a musical and a dramatic perspective.
Um, and I really think that he, like,
You know, there were things that I did that were out of my comfort zone, like the rap and I'm coming out.
And he definitely like was able to like coax something out of me that was way out of my comfort zone.
And by the end, it was something really fun and cool.
So, um, I, I really thought he was an amazing, um, producer and, and, um, person to work with.
